newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Lamfalussy says ERM2 "carrot" for non-EMU states.
newsitem.headline: Lamfalussy says ERM2 "carrot" for non-EMU states.

text.p: Alexandre Lamfalussy, president of the European Monetary Institute, said on Saturday a revamped European exchange rate mechanism dubbed "ERM2" could be used to influence monetary policies of non-EMU member states.

"Implementation (of ERM2) is on course and I think we have learned the lesson from ERM1 and therefore I think there is quite a high probability that ERM2 would work," Lamfalussy said during a lecture in Hungary.
"For the countries who will not be part of the monetary union right at the beginning ERM2 represents a carrot," he added. "It is through it that they can actually join the monetary union."
ERM2 is designed to provide a link between the euro and currencies of EU members which are not among the first to join the European Monetary Union (EMU) in 1999.
Hungary, Czech Republic and Poland are expected to qualify and be admitted to the EU early next century, even if their currencies do not immediately qualify them for EMU.
Lamfalussy said the new exchange rate mechanism, which will link the euro to other currencies in relatively wide trading bands, would have a stabilising influence on countries outside the EMU area.

"In other words, they have a vested interest in pursuing policies which do not lead to major misalignments because that would exclude them from the objective," he said at the lecture organised by European University Society for Financial Research (SUERF) and the Robert Triffin-Szirak Foundation.

"I'm quite sure that if in 1990-93 we had been at a similar stage of monetary union as we are today it would have been possible to deal with the 90-93 crisis in a different way," said Lamfalussy, who heads the forerunner of a European central bank.
Both the lira and sterling were ejected from the ERM in September 1992 during a crisis which nearly led to collapse of the rate mechanism.
